ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Mix of live and recorded lectures

We had synchronous, recorded lectures for 75 minutes twice a week. Professor Manning encouraged participation and discussion and he also liked to use the Breakout Rooms Zoom function at the beginning of the semester.
Small group breakout rooms
Weekly lectures on Zoom by the Professor and occasionally guest speakers.
N/A
Breakout rooms on Zoom - these were most helpful in meeting my peers in a virtual classroom!
About ~30 students showed up for synchronous lectures, the rest supposedly watched the recording
Mostly was a sort of lecture-seminar hybrid that I really enjoyed, with breakout sessions to discuss the sources with a sort of general discussion period and a few minutes of lecturing.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Honed my writing skills especially when employing multiple sources to build ideas.
A deeper understanding of the ancient world and how to study ancient materials

I learned about the historiography of the ancient economy (ancient economies?) and gained exposure to fields such as paleoclimatology, archaeology, Egyptology, and more. I learned a bit about the integration of primary and secondary sources throughout my essays.
How to analyze historical sources, new ways to study ancient history, the role of science in the study of ancient history
Learned everything Ancient Economy.
I thought this was a pretty cool/chill class and the Professor was nice. I learned a lot about history and economics and improved my essay writing skills.
I learned about comparative economic history, how it has been conducted traditionally and where the field is going.

Various aspects of the ancient economy, including school of thoughts, anicent techonology & demographics, some major economies (Greek, Roman, Hellenistic), as well as new areas of study such as climate.

Great overview of the Mediterranean world of the first millennium B.C.E. from the perspective of Economic History. The class was unlike other history courses that I have taken because studying pre-industrial Economics, especially of Antiquity, requires the integration of traditional history, science, and creativity. We learned different philosophies from notable historians about how to study Ancient Economies, including questions like the degree to which we can call behavior "economic" or "irrational" and the nuances of using ancient sources and archaeology with their sporadic preservation. I also learned some important general history of Greece, Egypt, the Hellenistic Era, and Rome.
This class provides an overview of the ancient economy through looking at written texts, archaeological evidence and scientific data.
To be completely honest. I gained nothing of value from this class due to how unorganized it was. The only thing I gained was stress due to how inconsistent and harsh of a grader Dr. Manning was.
A survey of the emerging field of 'Ancient Economy,' and the arts of historical inquiry, social science thinking/research, and archeological investigation.

This course not only provides a fairly good dive into the ancient economy but an introduction to some of the most fascinating and cutting-edge approaches of studying history and classics in general. A volcanic eruption will never again be just another event for me at least, and Ive developed a new appreciation for the role of coinage in classical antiquity.

I think I gained a better, unique insight about economics itself by taking this course. We discussed a lot on how to interpret the "ancient economy"  and as a result examined many different perspectives about economics, sociology, archaeology, etc. We didn't do a deep dive in any particular ancient economy, like the ancient Roman economy or the ancient Greek economy, but instead put them all in context of each other across the Mediterranean and across many centuries.
Synthesize information from different fields (e.g. combining climate data with papyrological evidence)

So much about the ancient economic institutions, and just what can be considered the ancient economy. It was also nice to not focus entirely on Rome, but mainly Hellenistic Greece and Egypt, very refreshing from other classical history courses. I really enjoyed learning about the current state of the field and the new sorts of analyses being used, even from scientific fields, and it was really cool to have some of the other researchers doing advanced work in the field pop in for guest lecture/discussions

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Three papers were the only graded assignments makes it hard to follow along with the class

The strengths of the course were the following: We read a mix of secondary and primary sources; we read current and older (20th c.) scholarship; we looked at different kinds of evidence and discussed their implications; we also enjoyed four guest lectures throughout the term. 

One weakness was that Professor Manning tended to repeat the material of the readings during lecture. Also, some classes were pure lecture while others were all discussion  the balance felt off. Part of this was due to the fact that we didn't have section, so Professor Manning was essentially combining a lecture with a section every week.
None, Manning did great.

Strengths - interesting content, nice Professor, cool guest speakers, not too much work, no discussion sections. Weaknesses - the final essay was somewhat tough, a bit more structure and clarity on expectations/grading would have been useful.

Strength: Very interesting classes + course materials. A rich variety of modes of instruction that made classes more engaging (breakout rooms, presentations, guest speakers, etc.)
Weakness: None that are glaring that I can think of

Strengths: The topics in the course are wide in range and interesting. There are sufficient readings into each topic and there are further readings that help students explore anything they are interested in. The guest lectures allow students to interact with edge-cutting historians & scientists in various areas (eg: shipwreck, ice-core study).

Improvement: There can be more direct sources.
I liked the course format and most weeks, the reading amount was quite manageable. No weaknesses really besides classes being remote this term.
The lecture and participation over zoom was a little tough but the readings were super interesting.

Strengths: in class seminars were recorded. Yes, thats it

Weaknesses: disorganized, unclear and harsh in terms of grading. In class discussions have very little to do with the assignments. Half the time we were behind on discussing the readings in class.

Strengths: Professor Manning's live lecture format which allows students to ask questions in real time as the lecture is happening (something not typical of the other history in-person live lectures I've taken pre-pandemic)

Weaknesses: Not all the reading was covered in the class, so I would recommend lessening the reading load per class.

The course material itself diverges from standard historical thinking sometimes and encourages students to change their pre-conceived notions of the ancient world. Its all very interesting, and the promotion of integrating scientific analysis with conventional history might be good for anyone aspiring to study history. The professors expertise in Ptolemaic Egyptian history also makes some of the material very new for experienced classicists. His guest lecturers also represent some of the most important minds working on the field at this moment. That said, the class can sometimes strawman conventional conceptions of the ancient economy too much, obsessing with Moses Finley when its clear all modern scholarship have abandoned his view. I must also say that his final assignment, a prcis that also needed to include 7 other sources as well as our own opinions, was a disjointed and self-contradictory request. I couldnt figure out what he really wanted there.

I think the biggest strength of the course is simply the subject matter, which is totally unique and fascinating even among Yale history courses. It really does give you a new perspective on antiquity and arguably even modern economics too. Professor was also very nice and accommodating considering the circumstances of Zoom learning and COVID. Also, the writing workload is relatively quite low, with only 3 papers for the whole semester.

Weaknesses: I think the class was too big given the format. We had 30-40 people but the class format was largely seminar-style, so as a result it felt a little difficult to participate in the discussions. Feedback on the essays was not very thorough, although this is hardly surprising given the large class size and no TA's.  Also, at times I think the big picture of the class was unclear, as it was easy to get lost since we were considering many different economies from different regions and time period.

Strength: interactive, exposure to various fields 

Weakness: lack of independent research-oriented learning/project (thus discussions generally limited to sources provided by Prof)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the professor did a good job overall

Professor Manning frequently used Breakout Rooms. Honestly, I enjoyed Breakout Rooms more than our larger discussions, since the class could sometimes draw ca. 35 people. At the same time, I don't think that all the time spent reporting back what each group discussed was that valuable (it felt repetitive). In order to accommodate people in different time zones, every lecture was recorded, which seemed to work out well.
None. Manning did great.

The virtual lectures worked well as students could ask questions and give immediate feedback.

The small breakout rooms felt a bit awkward as they slowed down the pace of the class period. In addition, the practice of all groups giving their answers quickly felt repetitive as there was little new to ask.

I think that this class worked fine the way it was structured now. I liked the fact that there were no discussion sections. I think perhaps grading rubrics and expectations could have been made a bit more clear.
Virtual office hours were great. Also the lectures were recorded which was convenient.
Variety in modes of instruction (mentioned earlier)
The breakout rooms discussions are excellent. Breaking three to four students into one room allows everyone to fully express their own thoughts and listen to every other's ideas.
Occasional Zoom Breakout Rooms to help the class discussion was a nice idea.

I loved that Professor Manning managed to seamlessly include guest lecturers. Professor Manning's willingness to always meet for office hours and get to know every student also helped online classes feel a tad less impersonal.
I think having a section for this class would be helpful in the zoom context since it was difficult to have whole class discussions during the online lecture.

Succeeded: recording seminars

Needs significant improvement: zoom breakouts (not much was gained from it)
The Breakout rooms on Zoom were most helpful for facilitating virtual learning as it allowed one to connect to his or her peers in the class. It also encouraged critical thinking.
I think the breakout rooms were nice and wished we did them more often, since it allowed me to discuss the readings in a smaller setting and get my views across more easily.

Success: "Pages" tool on Canvas made the readings and expectations very organized

Improvement: even with ~4 people breakout rooms, it felt like the "interactive" portions of the lecture were subsumed by students "reporting" back instead of having a dialogue amongst the whole class, perhaps having discussion sections would help

I really liked the more discussion based format of the course, even though it was listed as a lecture. I was much more engaged over zoom than in other classes and it was very interesting and not a boring slog like many zoom lectures are.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, there valuable information to be learned if you put in the time and effort

If you're interesting in Classics/the Near East/Egypt/economic history, I would recommend this course, with several caveats. The readings can be really interesting, but a lot of class time is just reinforcing the readings. Some interesting elements of the class (like the object of the day) petered out after a certain point in the semester. It also seemed like a lot of people stopped doing the readings, so our discussions got worse at the end of the semester. We didn't get a lot of feedback on essays (since there was no TA). Without being genuinely interested in the class material, it would be easy to lose motivation. However, the readings will spark many new ideas if you are interested in the material.

Yes, Prof. Manning is very engaging and knows a lot about ancient history, specifically the Graeco-Roman world and the eastern Med. His lectures are engaging and the guest speakers were very interesting. The essays aren't particularly challenging, so this makes a good 5th class if you find the topic interesting.
Yes. Manning is a great Professor. If you dont love ancient history, topic is a bit dry, but still a great survey course. Manning is a Yale gem.
Yes. The course is great for both history and econ students I think

Overall this class was pretty good. The prof was really nice and the material was interesting and simple. However, note that you do have to put some thought into all the assignments - especially the prompt for the final essay was rough, since you had to cite at least 10 syllabus readings and write a new history of the ancient economy (which is not easy). Would recommend as a chill and interesting 5th class, especially if you like writing essays.
Yes because as an economics student this was a very refreshing course that allowed me to look at the development of economies and our very definition of them.

Yes. This course provides a unique perspective of ancient history, one that not only covers what historically happened, but also analyzes why & how changes were made. The readings are interesting, and this course can be a great choice to anyone who is interested in learning more about the unique ancient economies.

Yes, especially for the student interested in Antiquity; there is so much economic thinking that the ancients had that we do not realize. I would say that it is advisable to have at least some background or interest in Antiquity (even a non-History major could have enough) to engage more fully with the material, but it is definitely fine for a first class in Antiquity.

I absolutely would! I knew nothing about the Ancient Economy and took this class because a friend spoke wonders of Professor Manning. They were right! Professor Manning managed to make a topic I knew nothing about accessible, without erasing the complexities and nuances of the field (which are many). He was always willing to clarify, to explain things further. He also humanized people who frankly previously felt very foreign to me. Ancient people left a far greater historical record than I had realized, and Professor Manning really helped make that come to life. I would absolutely recommend this class to a friend, but I would also tell them to take any class with Professor Manning. He is great.
I would recommend this class to those looking for a different and new way in which to learn about the ancient world.
I would not. The class is very tedious and the readings arent worth it considering how many people are didnt go over in class
Yes
Yes

Yes! Manning's 'Ancient Economy' is not just a history or economics course, but a comprehensive humanities survey that includes those two subjects and much more. You will treat humanistic questions differently after taking this course as well as being exposed to the many different approaches Manning employs to solve those questions.

Take the class if you are interested in the subject. Otherwise, don't take it because of the low workload evaluation on coursetable. The seminar/lecture was at times dry and unstructured, but professor Manning is a great person who is very knowledgeable in this field.
Its a very chill 5th credit.

Yes I would. There were things I weren't enthusiastic about, but I think this class has so much potential and might be improved upon in later years. The class material itself is absolutely fascinating and I think provides an invaluable perspective on antiquity and economics that one simply won't get elsewhere. The workload was relatively low--only 3 short papers and readings were average length. I think the class format/structure could be improved, as I think it was easy to fall behind and miss the big picture of Professor's points. There weren't many "lectures" or slides giving us facts about the ancient economy as much as it was seminar discussion about the readings we did, although it was unclear at times why we were doing the readings in the order we did or how it related to the other readings. Overall though, it's a fun, valuable class with not a large workload, and I'm very glad I took it.

This course is probably best suited for students with some prior exposure in a related field (not that it is required for enjoying or understanding the course content) because the most fun/exciting approach of this course is to combine seemingly unrelated fields of study. Without background in ancient history/economics, this course still is a fine survey of one specific school of thought in ancient economics, possible comparisons would be limited to provided course material.

Yes I would totally recommend this, especially if you're interested in economic history or pre-industrial history more broadly. And I really think econ majors should take this, to sort of break your mind out of the paradigm of modern economies and force yourself to understand different ways of economic organization. The workload is very reasonable, but the work is very intellectually stimulating and the readings are incredibly interesting and you come away with some great insight every day.
